name: Version 2.3.3
body:
## What's Changed
* feat: add example on how to retrieve property by @urubens in https://github.com/cytomine/Cytomine-python-client/pull/50
* feat: give a more explicit message in case of url redirection by @chlmarchal 
* feat: add software version as parameter of the software upload by @chlmarchal 
* Edit version parameter and specify it as optional @gvincke 

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/cytomine/Cytomine-python-client/compare/v2.3.1...v2.3.3

name: Version 2.3.1
body:
## What's Changed
* Fix the import of MutableSequence causing cytomine import to fail wit… by @benjamindorra in https://github.com/cytomine/Cytomine-python-client/pull/45
* style: try to respect pep8 by @urubens in https://github.com/cytomine/Cytomine-python-client/pull/47
* fix: backward compatibility with IMS v1.x & v2.x for upload endpoint by @urubens in https://github.com/cytomine/Cytomine-python-client/pull/46
* Minor fixes by @urubens in https://github.com/cytomine/Cytomine-python-client/pull/48

## New Contributors
* @benjamindorra made their first contribution in https://github.com/cytomine/Cytomine-python-client/pull/45

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/cytomine/Cytomine-python-client/compare/v2.3.0...v2.3.1

name: Version 2.2.2
body:
Add a Python json descriptor reader (by @urubens)
Update urllib3 (and dependent requests lib) and fix (by @urubens)
Add utils method for software (by @waliens)
Bug fix

name: Version 2.2.1
body: Patch for Tag and TagDomainAssociation export

name: Version 2.2.0
body:
Release of Cytomine-python-client (Version 2.2.0) : module of the [Cytomine](https://www.cytomine.org/) platform.

Please see [https://doc.cytomine.org/Admins](here) to know how to install Cytomine with Docker.

More information on [Cytomine website](http://www.cytomine.org/) and on our [online documentation](https://doc.cytomine.org).


**List of modifications :**
* Improvments with the domains and methods used for interaction with the Cytomine V3 (software, software user repository).
* Add domains tag et tag domain association
* Add utilitary method for annotation classification

**Thanks to :**
The [Cytomine research team](https://uliege.cytomine.org/) at Montefiore Institut (ULiège University)
The [Cytomine cooperative](https://cytomine.coop)

name: v2.1.1
body: Fix collection fetching error if max not defined with new core backend pagination

name: v2.0.0
body:
The information below is copied from [page dedicated to the new Python client in Cytomine documentation](http://doc.cytomine.be/display/DEVDOC/New+Python+client+usage).

## Changelog

This new version is a complete rewrite of the Python client and improves and adds a lot of features:

* Compatibility with Python 2.7 / 3+
* Logging with verbosity levels (standard Python logger)
* Use requests library to handle HTTP
* Collections are iterable
* Models attributes are written in the code: code is self-documented and ease auto-completion
* Cytomine class is a singleton and it is no longer necessary to pass it as parameter in every function
* Model and Collection are self managed
* CytomineJob class extends Cytomine and is thus a singleton where the current user is a user job

## Cytomine dependencies
This version is compatible with the following Cytomine components versions:
- Cytomine-core v1.2
- Cytomine-IMS v1.2

## Usage

### Connection

You need 3 parameters to connect :

1. The host (example: demo.cytomine.be)
2. Your public key
3. Your private key

It is recommended to use the `with` statement to establish the HTTP session between the client and the sever. The "with statement" block is a Python feature to efficiently deal with data flows.

```python
host = "demo.cytomine.be"
public_key = "XXX"
private_key = "XXX"
 
with Cytomine(host=host, public_key=public_key, private_key=private_key,
              verbose=logging.INFO) as cytomine:
	print(cytomine.current_user)
```

The verbose parameter allows to change the verbosity level. By default, it is set to INFO, which prints a summary of a resource when fetched, saved, updated or deleted. See the Python standard logging module for more information.

Another possibility to connect, especially for short scripts is to use the `connect()` method:

```python
cytomine = Cytomine.connect(host, public_key, private_key)
print(cytomine.current_user)
```
It is still possible to connect by simply instantiate the Cytomine class for backwards compatibility reasons but is deprecated.

### Model
A Cytomine resource (e.g. a project A) is an instance of a domain (e.g. Project). In the client, a resource is a Python object which is an instance of a model class describing its domain. Each object (an instance of model):

* has a set of attributes corresponding to resource attributes
* is managed itself through fetch(), save(), update() and delete() methods that communicate with the Cytomine-core server
* has some utilities to be serialized to JSON
* a dictionary of query parameters that will appear in the request: resource.json?param1=value1 (seldom used for models)

A simple example with a project resource:

```python
# ... Assume we are connected
id_ontology = 0
 
# Add a new project
# The save() method makes the appropriate HTTP POST request.
# Option 1
my_new_project = Project("my project name", id_ontology).save()
# Option 2
my_new_project = Project()
my_new_project.name = "my project name"
my_new_project.ontology = id_ontology
my_new_project.save()
 
 
# Get the project from server. 
# The fetch() method makes the appropriate HTTP GET request.
# Option 1
my_new_project2 = Project().fetch(id=my_new_project.id)
# Option 2
my_new_project2 = Project()
my_new_project2.id = my_new_project.id
my_new_project2.fetch()
 
 
# Update a project
# The update() method makes the appropriate HTTP PUT request.
# Option 1
my_new_project.name = "Another name"
my_new_project.update()
# Option 2
my_new_project.update(name="Another name")
 
 
# Delete a project
# The delete() method makes the appropriate HTTP DELETE request.
# Option 1
my_new_project.delete()
# Option 2
Project().delete(id=my_new_project.id)
```
#### Supplementary actions
In some cases, the server provides supplementary actions for some resources. These actions are encapsulated in additional methods for the model. Please refer to the [documentation](http://doc.cytomine.be/display/DEVDOC/New+Python+client+usage#NewPythonclientusage-Supplementaryactions) for examples of such supplementary actions.

### Collection
A collection is a list of objects that have the same model. A collection is fetched with fetch() method.

For example, to get the list of all projects you have access to:
```python
projects = ProjectCollection().fetch()
print(projects)
for project in projects:
	print(project)
	print(project.name)
```

The Collection class extends the Python MutableSequence class. You can thus work with a collection like with any Python list:
```python
projects = ProjectCollection().fetch()
print(len(projects))
print(projects[0])
print([project.name for project in projects])
```

#### Filtering
The API often allows to filter a list of resources with an other resource, by specifiying it in the URI. The filtering by URI is performed using the fetch_with_filter() method. The list of allowed filters for a collection is given by mycollection.filters(). 

```python
projects = ProjectCollection().fetch()
print(projects.filters()) # None, user, software, ontology
 
# None indicates the collection can be fetched without any filter
ProjectCollection().fetch()
 
# Get the list of projects of a particular user
id_user = 0
ProjectCollection().fetch_with_filter("user", id_user)
 
# Get the list of projects linked to a particular software
id_software = 0
ProjectCollection().fetch_with_filter("software", id_software)
 
# Get all projects that share the same ontology
id_ontology = 0
ProjectCollection().fetch_with_filter("ontology", id_ontology)
```

It will make the appropriate GET request, e.g. : GET /api/ontology/{id_ontology}/project.json

The behavior of collection requests can sometimes be modified with some query parameters. In the case of collections, these query parameters are the attributes of the Collection class. For example, we can obtain the list of online users with a query parameter:

```python
UserCollection(online=True).fetch()
# Get the list of online users
# => GET /api/user.json?online=true
 
id_project = 0
UserCollection(online=True).fetch_with_filter("project", id_project)
# Get the list of online users on a particular project
# => GET /api/project/{id_project}/user.json?online=true
```

#### Particular case: collection of annotations
A list of annotations can be filtered with many filters (project, user, image, term, ...). The only way given by the API to filter a list of annotations is to use query parameters. 

```python
id_project = 0
id_users = [1, 2]
annotations = AnnotationCollection(project=id_project, users=id_users, showWKT=True).fetch()
# => GET /api/annotation.json?showBasic=true&showMeta=true&showWKT=true&project=0&users=1,2
print(annotations)
```

name: Version 1.1
body:
Release of Cytomine-python-client (Version 1.1) for the [Cytomine](http://www.cytomine.be/) platform.

When using our software, we kindly ask you to cite our website url and related publications in all your work (publications, studies, oral presentations,...) using Cytomine. In particular, we recommend to cite ([Marée et al., Bioinformatics 2016](http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btw013)) paper, and to use our [logo](http://www.cytomine.be/logo/logo.png) when appropriate. See our license files for additional details.

Please see [http://doc.cytomine.be/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=10715266](here) to know how to install Cytomine with Docker.

More information on [Cytomine website](http://www.cytomine.be/) and on our [online documentation](http://doc.cytomine.be/).

name: Global Open Source release
body:
This version of Cytomine-python-client is compatible with the version 1.0 of Cytomine-IMS & Cytomine-Core.

Official 1.0 Open Source release of Cytomine-python-client associated to the paper (Marée et al., Bioinformatics 2016) !

When using our software, you agree to cite our website url and related publications in all your work (publications, studies, oral presentations,...). In particular, you agree to cite our (Marée et al., Bioinformatics 2016) paper, and to use our logo when appropriate. See our license files for additional details.
- URL: http://www.cytomine.be/
- Logo: http://www.cytomine.be/logo/logo.png
- Scientific paper: Raphaël Marée, Loïc Rollus, Benjamin Stévens, Renaud Hoyoux, Gilles Louppe, Rémy Vandaele, Jean-Michel Begon, Philipp Kainz, Pierre Geurts and Louis Wehenkel. Collaborative analysis of multi-gigapixel imaging data using Cytomine, Bioinformatics, DOI: 10.1093/bioinformatics/btw013, 2016. http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/btw013?ijkey=dQzEgmXVozFRPPf&keytype=ref

More information on [Cytomine website](http://cytomine.be/) and on our [online documentation](http://doc.cytomine.be).
